Geoinformation System¶

Description for basic attributes to be added here

Source Code¶

This module contains source code to analyze geographical information (gis) data. It includes two classes where on inherits from the other. The class purposes are especially suited for visualization of the data

Furthermore, ut contains methods to generate features out of Geographical Information System (GIS). Note that all of those classes are using the BaseEstimator and TransformerMixin classes from the scikit-learn bases classes. In order to use the fit_transform implemented by the scikit-learn, every single Feature Transformer needs to have a fit and transform method. The fit methods returns the object itself and is therefore not documented

class gis.GisAnalyzer(data: Union[str, Sequence[str]], lat: str = '', lon: str = '')[source]¶

Bases: baseattrs.BaseStats

A class used to visualise geographical data based on latitude and longitude columns

__init__(data: Union[str, Sequence[str]], lat: str = '', lon: str = '')[source]¶

Initializes a GIS Analyzer object. It expects a DataFrame as input. Furthermore, it has the lat and lon columns which are used for defining the latitude and longitude. They do not have to be set upon object creation but can be reset using the corresponding set_lat and set_lon methods. It also has three mapping objects indicating the map style, a color list and a grad list.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – the data holding the geographical latitude and longitude columns

  • lat (str) – the latitude feature column name

  • lon (str) – the longitude feature column name

set_lat(lat: str) → gis.GisAnalyzer[source]¶

Resets the name of the latitude column

Parameters

lat (str) – the label oft the latitude columns

Returns

the object with its lat attribute reset

Resets the name of the longitude column

Parameters

the object with its lon attribute reset

A property yielding the first latitude entry.

Returns

the first entry of the latitude column

property initial_lon¶

A property yielding the first longitude entry

Returns

the first entry of the longitude column

property coordinates¶

A property putting the latitude and longitude to a list. Used as an alias to avoid writing [lat,lon] any time the GIS is plotted

Returns

a list of the latitude and longitude

Creates a HeatMap with the coordinates found in the latitude and longitude columns.

  • zoom_start (int) – set the initial zoom of the map

Generates a interactive HeatMap which enables a geographic visualization by time.

  • zoom_start (int) – set the initial zoom of the map

  • time_var (str) – the label of the time column by which the data is analyzed by

generate_map_cluster(style=6, zoom_start=12, include_heat_map: bool = True)[source]¶

Generates a map which includes cluster depending on the GIS distances between the different points. The Cluster itself depends on the zooming level

Parameters

  • style (int) – indicates which style of the map to be used

  • zoom_start (int) – set the initial zoom of the map

  • include_heat_map (bool) – a flag which indicates if an additional HeatMap shall be added to the Map

Returns

simple_plot(**options: Mapping[str])[source]¶

Generates a simple scatter plot of the coordinates. The scatter is an abstraction of the data by not include the actual map. It can be used to quickly have a look on a basic map.

Parameters

options – the seaborn scatter plot options

Returns

class gis.GisAnalyzerWithClusterLabel(data: Union[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame], lat: str = '', lon: str = '', cluster_label: Union[str, Sequence, None] = None)[source]¶

Bases: gis.GisAnalyzer

A class derived from the GisAnalyzer used to visualise geographical data based on latitude and longitude columns and take into account cluster labels

__init__(data: Union[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame], lat: str = '', lon: str = '', cluster_label: Union[str, Sequence, None] = None)[source]¶

Initializes a GIS Analyzer object. It expects a DataFrame as input. Furthermore, it has the lat and lon columns which are used for defining the latitude and longitude. They do not have to be set upon object creation but can be reset using the corresponding set_lat and set_lon methods. Additionally, a set of labels can be indicated as well. The purpose hereby lies especially in visualizing geographic clusters. It also has three mapping objects indicating the map style, a color list and a grad list.

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – the data holding the geographical latitude and longitude columns

  • lat (str) – the latitude feature column name

  • lon (str) – the longitude feature column name

  • cluster_label (list) – single or multiple column labels indicating the clustering label

simple_plot_by_cluster_labels(**options: Mapping[str])[source]¶

Plots the geographical data by all the different cluster labels.

Parameters

options (dict) – options used by the simple_plot

Returns

class gis.GisBasicTransformer(lat: str, lon: str, round_factor: int = 0, radian: bool = True)[source]¶

Bases: gis._BaseClass, sklearn.base.BaseEstimator, sklearn.base.TransformerMixin

Derives primitive feature transformation for GIS The primitive transformations are:

  • round: round the GIS to a specific digit length. This can be considered as a feature as it groups together points with similar values. It reduces information but reduces the dimension of the feature

  • radians: a simple transformation to get the radians of the GIS.

__init__(lat: str, lon: str, round_factor: int = 0, radian: bool = True)[source]¶

Initializes a primitive feature creator object

Parameters

  • lat (str) – the column name of the latitude column

  • lon (str) – the column name of the longitude column

  • round_factor (int) – if set and >0, it indicate the number of digits to round the geo data.

  • radian (bool) – a flag indicating if the radians shall be derived

fit(X, y=None, **kwargs)[source]¶
transform(X: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]¶

Transforms the DataFrame. Checks the both arguments and applies the respective function if the condition hols (round >0; radian = True)

Parameters

X – the original DataFrame

Returns

class gis.GisDistance(lat_1: str, lon_1: str, lat_2: str, lon_2: str, label: str = 'distance')[source]¶

Bases: gis._BaseClass, sklearn.base.BaseEstimator, sklearn.base.TransformerMixin

Calculates the haversine distance between two geo points

__init__(lat_1: str, lon_1: str, lat_2: str, lon_2: str, label: str = 'distance')[source]¶

Initializes an object which calculates the Haversine distance between two points

Parameters

  • lat_1 (str) – the column name of the first point’s latitude column

  • lon_1 (str) – the column name of the first point’s longitude column

  • lat_2 (str) – the column name of the second point’s latitude column

  • lon_2 (str) – the column name of the second point’s longitude column

  • label (str) – the column label of the newly created column capturing the distance

fit(X, y=None, **kwargs)[source]¶
haversine_distance(row)[source]¶

The formulae for the haversine distance. It takes a DataFrame’s row as an input arguments, derives the four GIS points and applies the Formula to it.

Parameters

row (pd.DataFrame) – a DataFrame row

Returns

the haversine distance for the row

transform(X: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]¶

Applies the haversine_distance formula to all rows and saves the value in a newly generated column

Parameters

X – the original DataFrame

Returns

class gis.GisCluster(lat: str, lon: str, kmeans: bool = True, kmeans_params: Mapping[str] = None, dbscan: bool = True, dbscan_params: Mapping[str] = None, birch: bool = True, birch_params: Mapping[str] = None, hdbscan: bool = True, hdbscan_params: Mapping[str] = None, agglomerative: bool = True, agglomerative_params: Mapping[str] = None)[source]¶

Bases: gis._BaseClass, sklearn.base.BaseEstimator, sklearn.base.TransformerMixin

Applies Machine Learning based clustering on the GIS data.

__init__(lat: str, lon: str, kmeans: bool = True, kmeans_params: Mapping[str] = None, dbscan: bool = True, dbscan_params: Mapping[str] = None, birch: bool = True, birch_params: Mapping[str] = None, hdbscan: bool = True, hdbscan_params: Mapping[str] = None, agglomerative: bool = True, agglomerative_params: Mapping[str] = None)[source]¶

Creates an object that applies a possibly multitude of different clustering algorithms on the data

Parameters

  • lat (str) – the column name of the latitude column

  • lon (str) – the column name of the longitude column

  • kmeans (bool) – a flag indicating if the k-means clustering algorithm is applied

  • kmeans_params (dict) – indicates k-means clustering hyper parameters

  • dbscan (bool) – a flag indicating if the DBSCAN clustering algorithm is applied

  • dbscan_params (dict) – indicates DBSCAN clustering hyper parameters

  • birch (bool) – a flag indicating if the BIRCH clustering algorithm is applied

  • birch_params (dict) – indicates BIRCH clustering hyper parameters

  • hdbscan (bool) – a flag indicating if the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm is applied

  • hdbscan_params (dict) – indicates HDBSCAN clustering hyper parameters

  • agglomerative (bool) – a flag indicating if the Agglomerative clustering algorithm is applied

  • agglomerative_params (dict) – indicates Agglomerative clustering hyper parameters

fit(X, y=None, **kwargs)[source]¶
transform(X: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]¶

Applies the clustering based on which algorithm with respective parameters have been specified. For each clustering algorithm set to True, the clustering is performed using the respective algorithm’s hyper parameters

Parameters

X – The initial DataFrame

Returns
